components.AlgorithmSettingsModal.algori.name: Fixed Order
components.AlgorithmSettingsModal.algori.description: The learning elements are presented in a predetermined order.

components.AlgorithmSettingsModal.algori.name: Graf
components.AlgorithmSettingsModal.algori.description: This algorithm is based on the learning adaptive mechanism by Graf et al. It calculates the learning path based on the learning style of the learner.

components.AlgorithmSettingsModal.algori.name: ACO
components.AlgorithmSettingsModal.algori.description: The Ant Colony Algorithm (ACO) is inspired by the behavior of ant workers. It calculates the learning path by simulating ants who leave behind pheromones to mark the best path.

components.AlgorithmSettingsModal.algori.name: Genetic Algorithm
components.AlgorithmSettingsModal.algori.description: Based on natural selection, it combines learning paths to evolve the best one over several iterations.

components.AlgorithmSettingsModal.wrongR: You are not authorized to change the algorithm
components.BasicNode.recommendedExercise: This exercise is recommended for you.
components.ContactForm.briefDescription: Give a brief description of your request
components.ContactForm.submitError: The submit function has been called and an error occurred.
components.CourseCard.deleteTooltip: Delete Course with all of its Content
components.CreateAlgorithmTable.initialA: Please select an algorithm for the learning path calculation.
components.CreateDefaultLearningPathTabl: You are required to establish your own didactic learning pathway through your learning content. This pathway is an unchangeable sequence of learning elements that you would essentially recommend to every student. It acts as a general guideline for those whose data is not yet sufficient to enable the calculation of an adaptive learning path. Moreover, students in HASKI always have the option to choose and follow the didactic learning pathway you have designed.
All elements must either be selected or deactivated
components.DeleteEntityModal.confirmLabe: and all its content will be permanently deleted from the HASKI system (content in Moodle remains unaffected).
components.DeleteEntityModal.description: This action will permanently remove all data and associated content from the HASKI system. This action cannot be undone. Content in Moodle remains unaffected.

components.LearningElementRatingDashboar: This page fills with information about the rating of learning elements as soon as you begin to work on exercises.
On {{timestamp}} the rating was {{value}} with a deviation of {{deviation}}.
The progression of the average learning element rating
The current normalized average rating deviation is {{value}}.
The trend of the normalized average rating deviation is {{value}}.
The current average rating of all learning elements
The current normalized average rating value is {{value}}.
The trend of the normalized average rating value is {{value}}.
The average learning element rating per topic
components.LearningElementRatingInfo.das: This dashboard provides information on the current rating of learning elements and presents them in various forms.
components.LearningElementRatingInfo.lin: The line graph and the table are shown below. They display the average ratings of all learning elements over time and thus provide an overview of the development of the level of difficulty. While the line graph is a graphical representation, the table provides a detailed insight into the previous ratings.
components.LearningElementRatingInfo.rat: The current rating of all learning elements is indicated by a value and its standard deviation in the top left-hand corner. It provides an overview of the current average level of difficulty of all learning elements across all topics. The initial values for the rating and standard deviation are 1500 and 350 respectively. In order to be able to estimate the rating, the values have been normalized with the current maximums. In addition, trends provide information about the current development.
components.LearningElementRatingInfo.spi: The spider graph at the top right shows the average rating of all learning elements per topic and thus enables a comparison of the difficulty of different areas.

components.ListKQuestions.question: I am going through my notes and creating an outline with the most important points.
I create brief summaries of lecture notes, scripts, or literature with the main ideas.
I compile important technical terms and definitions into my own lists.
I try to relate new terms or theories to terms and theories that I already know.
I come up with concrete examples for specific learning content.
I relate what I am learning to my own experiences.
I question whether the text I am working on is really convincing.
I approach most texts critically.
I also critically examine what I am learning.
I memorize a self-created overview of the most important technical terms.
I memorize rules, technical terms, or formulas.
I memorize the study material based on scripts or other notes as much as possible.
I formulate learning goals that I then orient my learning towards.
I think about how I want to learn before I start learning.
I do not plan my approach to learning.
To identify knowledge gaps, I recap the most important content without using my notes for help.
I ask myself questions about the material to check whether I understand everything.
If the study material includes questions or tests, I use them to test myself.
I change my learning technique when I encounter difficulties.
I change my study plans if I realize that they cannot be implemented.
If I realize that my approach to learning is not successful, I change it.
I find it difficult to stay focused.
I am easily distracted while studying.
I am easily distracted when studying.
If I have set a certain amount of material to learn, I try to achieve it.
I do not give up even if the material is very difficult or complex.
I also study late at night and on weekends if necessary.
I stick to a specific schedule when studying.
I schedule the hours that I spend studying each day through a timetable.
I set a specific duration of time before each study phase.
I work on texts or tasks together with my fellow students.
I take time to discuss the material with my fellow students.
If something is unclear to me, I ask a fellow student for advice.
If certain content is not yet clear to me, I look for additional literature.
I gather missing information from various sources (e.g. lecture notes, books, technical journals).
If my notes are incomplete, I refer to additional literature.
I design my environment so that I am as little distracted from learning as possible.
I always sit in the same place to study.
My workspace is designed so that I can find everything quickly.

components.Menubar.closeDialog: Are you sure you want to close the Questionnaire? Unsent answers will not be saved.

components.PrivacyModal.declined: You cannot access HASKI without accepting the essential cookies.

components.RatingInfoDrawerButton.open: Open the drawer for further dashboard information
components.ResultDescriptionILS.active-m: Your information processing tends to be active. It is recommended that you always create opportunities for yourself to process new information in the course of practical experiments and discussions with fellow students. This tends to help you learn faster.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.active-s: Your information processing is preferably active. It is recommended that you always create opportunities for yourself to process new information in the course of practical experiments and discussions with fellow students. This tends to help you learn faster.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.balanced: of the four dimensions, you do not show any clear tendency. This indicates that you are not sure about the
of information can make use of both poles of the dimension. According to the ILS result, you have the skillset to adapt flexibly here.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.everythi: You do not show a clear tendency in any of the dimensions. This indicates that you can make use of both poles of the dimensions in the processing, perception, presentation and organization of information. According to the ILS results, you have the skillset to adapt flexibly here. The recommendation is therefore to continue learning in this balance.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.global-m: With regard to the organization of information, there is a significant tendency for a global approach. This results in the recommendation to first obtain an overview of the context and the entirety of the topic when learning new content.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.global-s: With regard to the organization of information, there is a significant preference for a global approach. This results in the recommendation to first obtain an overview of the context and the entirety of the topic when learning new content.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.intuitiv: You prefer rather an intuitive perception of information. It seems beneficial that you first learn new information based on principles and ideas. Exposure to additional theoretical literature can improve your understanding.

You prefer an intuitive perception of information. It seems beneficial that you first learn new information based on principles and ideas. Exposure to additional theoretical literature can improve your understanding.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.reflecti: Your information processing tends to be reflective. It is recommended that you always create opportunities for yourself to think intensively about new information before you put it into practice or experiment with it. This tends to help you learn faster.

Your information processing is preferably reflective. It is recommended that you always create opportunities for yourself to think intensively about new information before you put it into practice or experiment with it. This tends to help you learn faster.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.sensory-: You prefer rather a sensory perception of information. It seems beneficial that you learn new information based on facts or experiments. Dealing with examples you have thought up yourself can increase your learning speed.

You prefer a sensory perception of information. It seems beneficial that you learn new information based on facts or experiments. Dealing with examples you have thought up yourself can increase your learning speed.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.sequenti: With regard to the organization of information, there is a significant tendency for sequential learning. This results in the recommendation to first create a hierarchical structure of the content when learning new content and then to work through it step by step.

With regard to the organization of information, there is a significant preference for sequential learning. This results in the recommendation to first create a hierarchical structure of the content when learning new content and then to work through it step by step.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.verbal-m: In terms of presenting information, you tend to prefer a verbal focus. When dealing with difficult and complex content, you may find it helpful to verbalize it using your own written summaries or audio recordings to facilitate their learning.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.verbal-s: In terms of presenting information, you prefer a verbal focus. When dealing with difficult and complex content, you may find it helpful to verbalize it using your own written summaries or audio recordings to facilitate their learning.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.visual-m: In terms of presenting information, you tend to prefer a visual focus. When dealing with difficult and complex content, it may help you to visualize it using graphs, charts, or the like to facilitate your learning.
components.ResultDescriptionILS.visual-s: In terms of presenting information, you prefer a visual focus. When dealing with difficult and complex content, it may help you to visualize it using graphs, charts, or the like to facilitate your learning.
components.ResultDescriptionListK.attent: In terms of internal resource management strategies, it is clear to see that you are currently finding it difficult to focus. It would probably be beneficial if you try to create a suitable environment with as few disruptive factors as possible to make your learning more effective. In terms of external resource management strategies, it is clear to see that you should pay attention to their suitability when designing your learning environment.
Attention and learning environment have a value below 3

In terms of internal resource management strategies, it is clear to see that you are currently finding it difficult to focus. It would probably be beneficial if you try to create a suitable environment with as few disruptive factors as possible to make your learning more effective. It would be beneficial if you try to find a study group with fellow student friends. This will give you the opportunity to deepen content in discussion as well as gain valuable other perspectives.
Attention and learning with classmates have a value below 3

components.StatisticsMenu.title: Statistics
components.StudentRatingDashboard.empty: This page fills with information about your rating as soon as you begin to work on exercises.
components.StudentRatingDashboard.histog: The rating distribution of all students
You are above {{percentage}}% of all students with a rating of {{value}}.
components.StudentRatingDashboard.lineGr: On {{timestamp}} your rating was {{value}} with a deviation of {{deviation}}.
The progression of your average rating
components.StudentRatingDashboard.rating: Your current average normalized rating deviation is {{value}}.
The trend of your average normalized rating deviation is {{value}}.
Your current normalized average rating value is {{value}}.
The trend of your average normalized rating value is {{value}}.
components.StudentRatingInfo.dashboardTe: This dashboard provides you with information about your current rating and displays it in various forms.
components.StudentRatingInfo.histogramTe: In the middle is the histogram. It provides an overview of the distribution of the average ratings of all students and is intended to enable a comparison with your rating, which is highlighted.
components.StudentRatingInfo.lineGraphTe: The line graph and table are shown below. They display your average rating over time and thus provide an overview of the development of your knowledge level. While the line graph is a graphical representation, the table provides a detailed insight into your previous ratings.
components.StudentRatingInfo.ratingText: Your current rating is shown at the top left by a value and its standard deviation. It provides an overview of your current average level of knowledge across all topics. The initial values for the rating and standard deviation are 1500 and 350 respectively. In order to be able to estimate the rating, the values have been normalized with the current maximums. In addition, trends provide information about the current development.
components.StudentRatingInfo.spiderGraph: The spider graph at the top right shows your average rating per topic, allowing you to compare your knowledge in the different areas.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I understand something better after I
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: have tried it.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: have thought about it.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I would rather be perceived as
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: imaginative.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: innovative.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I think about what I did yesterday, I tend to remember
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: images.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: words.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I tend to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: understand the details of a topic, but not quite grasp the overall structure.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: understand the overall structure, but not quite grasp the details.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I learn something new, it helps me to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: talk about it.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: think about it.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: If I were a teacher, I would prefer to teach a course that focuses on
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: facts and situations from real life.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: ideas and theories.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I prefer to receive new information through
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: pictures, diagrams, charts, and maps.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: written instructions over oral information.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: Once I
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: understand all the components, I understand the big picture.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: understand the big picture, I understand how the components fit together.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: In a study group working on difficult material, I am more likely to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: be active and contribute my own ideas.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: hold back and listen.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I find it easier to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: learn facts.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: learn concepts.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: In a document with many pictures and tables, I am likely to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: examine the pictures and diagrams carefully.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: focus on the written text.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When solving mathematical problems,
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: I usually work step by step towards the solution.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: I often see only the solutions but then have difficulty finding the steps to get there.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: In the courses I have taken so far,
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: I have usually gotten to know many of the other students.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: I have rarely gotten to know many of the other students.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When reading non-fiction texts, I prefer something that
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: teaches me new facts or shows me how to do something.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: gives me new ideas to think about.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I like teachers who
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: use many diagrams to present content.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: take a lot of time to explain.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When analyzing a story or novel,
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: I think about the events and try to put them together to find the themes.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: I know what the themes are after I finish reading and then have to go back to find the events that illustrate them.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When starting a homework assignment, I am more likely to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: start working on the solution right away.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: try to fully understand the assignment first.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I prefer the idea of
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: certainty.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: theory.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I remember best what I
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: see.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: hear.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: For me, it is more important that a teacher
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: presents the material in clear, building steps.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: gives me an overall picture and relates the material to other topics.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I prefer to learn
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: in a study group.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: alone.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I would rather be characterized as
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: paying careful attention to the details of my work.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: being creative in how I do my work.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When given directions to a new place, I prefer
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: a map.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: written instructions.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I learn
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: at a fairly steady pace. If I study hard, I will eventually get it.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: in bursts. I am totally confused and then suddenly it all makes sense.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I would rather
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: try things out.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: think about how I will do something.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When engaging with content in my free time, I prefer producers who
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: clearly state what they mean.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: deliver things in a creative, interesting way.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I see a diagram or sketch in a course, I am most likely to remember
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: the picture.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: what the teacher said about it.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When looking at information material, I tend to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: focus on the details and miss the big picture.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: try to understand the big picture before diving into the details.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I can remember something more easily,
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: that I have done.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: that I have thought a lot about.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I have to fulfill a task, I prefer
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: to find a way and perfect it.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: to always come up with new ways to get it done.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: If someone shows me data, I prefer
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: tables and graphs.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: a text that summarizes the results.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I write an academic paper, I am more inclined to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: work on the introduction of the essay (thinking or writing) and then proceed.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: work on different parts of the essay (thinking or writing) and then arrange them.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I have to work on a group project, I prefer to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: conduct a 'group brainstorming' where everyone contributes their ideas.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: do an individual brainstorming and then come together as a group to compare ideas.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I consider it a great compliment to call someone
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: reasonable.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: imaginative.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I meet new people at a party, I am more likely to remember
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: what they looked like.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: what they said about themselves.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I learn about a new topic, I prefer
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: to focus on that topic and learn as much as possible about it.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: to try to make connections between that topic and related topics.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I am considered to be more
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: open-minded.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: reserved.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I prefer courses that focus on
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: concrete material (facts, data).
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: abstract material (concepts, theories).

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: For my entertainment, I would rather
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: watch a movie or series.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: read a book or listen to an audiobook.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: Some teachers begin their classes with an overview of the content. Such outlines are
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: somewhat helpful.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: very helpful.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: The idea of group assignments with a shared grade for all group members
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: sounds good to me.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: does not appeal to me.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I perform longer calculations,
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: I tend to repeat all my steps and carefully check my work.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: checking my work is tiring and I have to force myself to do it.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: I can mentally visualize places I have been to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: very well and in quite detail.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: with difficulty and usually with little detail.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.question: When I solve problems in a group, it is more likely that
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer1: I think about the steps of the problem-solving process.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsLong.answer2: I think about the possible consequences or applications of the solution in different areas.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: In a study group working on difficult material, I am more likely to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer1: be active and contribute my own ideas.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: hold back and listen.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: I would rather be perceived as
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: innovative.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: I prefer to receive new information through
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: written instructions over oral information.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: I tend to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer1: understand the details of a topic, but not quite grasp the overall structure.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: understand the overall structure, but not quite grasp the details.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: In the courses I have taken so far,
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer1: I have usually gotten to know many of the other students.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: I have rarely gotten to know many of the other students.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: When reading non-fiction texts, I prefer something that
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer1: teaches me new facts or shows me how to do something.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: gives me new ideas to think about.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: I remember best what I
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: hear.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: Once I
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer1: understand all the components, I understand the big picture.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: understand the big picture, I understand how the components fit together.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: I prefer to learn
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: alone.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: When engaging with content in my free time, I prefer producers who
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: deliver things in a creative, interesting way.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: When I see a diagram or sketch in a course, I am most likely to remember
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: what the teacher said about it.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: When analyzing a story or novel,
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer1: I think about the events and try to put them together to find the themes.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: I know what the themes are after I finish reading and then have to go back to find the events that illustrate them.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: I would rather
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: think about how I will do something.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: I prefer courses that focus on
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: abstract material (concepts, theories).

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: For my entertainment, I would rather
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: read a book or listen to an audiobook.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: Some teachers begin their classes with an overview of the content. Such outlines are
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: very helpful.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: I can remember something more easily,
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: that I have thought a lot about.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: When I perform longer calculations,
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer1: I tend to repeat all my steps and carefully check my work.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: checking my work is tiring and I have to force myself to do it.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: I can mentally visualize places I have been to
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer1: very well and in quite detail.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: with difficulty and usually with little detail.

components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.question: When I solve problems in a group, it is more likely that
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer1: I think about the steps of the problem-solving process.
components.TableILSQuestions.ilsShort.answer2: I think about the possible consequences or applications of the solution in different areas.

components.TableILSQuestions.introductio: Following this you will be asked questions that pertain to your style of information processing and organization, perception, and preferred presentation.  For each question, pick one of the two options that fits you best. If both or neither of the response options apply to you, then choose the one that tends to apply more often. These questions are based on the Index of Learning Styles (Felder & Solomon 1991).
components.TableListKQuestions.introduct: Following this you will be asked questions about what learning strategies you use. You will find a list of different learning activities. Please indicate how frequently each activity occurs for you. You can rate your answers from very rarely (1) to very often (5). The questions presented are based on the LIST-K (Klingsieck, 2019), which is a shortened version of the LIST (Wild & Schiefele, 1994).
components.TableRemoteTopics.title: Available topics
components.TopicCard.deleteTooltip: Delete Topic with all of its Content

body: Production of learning elements in the field of software engineering with a multi-stage review process
Conception of a literature-based category system for the typification of the learning elements
Collection and analysis of learning analytics with persistence in a Learning Record Store (data lake)
Recording of student behavior through Moodle and frontend in the form of statements according to the xAPI standard
Creation and implementation of designs for student and teacher dashboards
Development of multiple Moodle Plugins (xAPI, Moodle Theme and H5P-Report Feature)
Communication with Moodle using the provided REST-API
LTI based communication between frontend and Moodle
React-frontend-development (modular development using components and pages)
Jest-frontend and Pytest-backend testing
Development of a CI/CD pipeline for frontend and backend in GitHub using SonarLint
Python-backend-development
Communication between frontend and backend using API endpoints with persistence in a Postgres database
Branch-focused development with review process on GitHub
Code based inline source documentation in the form of comments in frontend and backend
Theoretical preliminary conceptualization of an adaptive learning system
Further development of reliable, validated, and shortened questionnaire versions of the ILS and LIST-K using methods such as factor analysis, exhaustive feature selection, and Bayesian networks.
Modeling the individual level of knowledge using a rating system
Modeling student characteristics such as learning style and learning strategy
Literature research on adaptive learning systems, learning analytics, Knowledge Tracing, rating systems, large language models und natural language processing
Conception of a tool for the evaluation of free text tasks using large language models and natural language processing
Evaluation algorithms for various questionnaires (Index of Learning Styles - ILS and Learning Strategies in Studies, shortened - LIST-K)
Design, implementation and application of AI algorithms (e.g. ant colony algorithm and genetic algorithm) to generate individualized learning paths in a multidimensional hypercube
Implementation and application of literature-based algorithms based on the learning style (e.g. according to Graf et al. 2010)
Collaboration between frontend, backend and Moodle for the automatic generation of learning paths for students
Planning and implementation of triangulated (quantitative and qualitative) evaluations of the frontend and learning elements
Elaboration of the findings in the form of peer-reviewed contributions at scientific conferences
Dissemination work (design of flyers, posters and roll-ups)
Attendance at pertinent and technically relevant (international) conferences
Internal and external exchange at workshops and network meetings

pages.aboutus.introductionBody: HASKI is a joint project of the three Bavarian universities OTH Regensburg, Aschaffenburg UAS & Kempten UAS and comprises over 20, lecturers, scientific assistants, student assistants and people involved in the administration.
pages.aboutus.membersAschaffenburgBody:
Project Lead:
Prof. Dr.-Ing. Jörg Abke

Employees:
Prof. Dr. Galia Weidl, Isabell Hock, Yeimy Valencia, Paul Schoppel, Julian Manz

Former:
Doris Rebitzer, Marc Normann, PhD. Iryna Sapsai, Michael Münch

Former: Dominik Bittner

pages.aboutus.quotesBody.quote: "What is special about HASKI's adaptive learner model is that it adapts to the learner and not the other way around - as is usually the case. This puts the learner at the center of the learning process."
pages.aboutus.quotesBody.name: Prof. Dr. Georg Hagel

pages.contact.error: An error occurred while sending your feedback. Please try again later.
pages.contact.success: Your feedback has been sent successfully.

pages.glossary.elements.definition: Adaptability describes a system’s ability to be changed through external actions that modify its settings. In HASKI, both teachers and learners can adapt the system. For example, teachers can intervene in suggested learning paths, while learners can adjust basic settings such as colors or configure their own sequence of learning elements.
pages.glossary.elements.sources: Bartel, Dörringer & Klopp, 2022a; Petko & Reusser, 2005, p. 188; Zens, 2005

pages.glossary.elements.definition: Adaptivity is present when a system autonomously adjusts to input (e.g., test results, processing speed, or learning paths). In this context, adaptive learning refers to adapting learning offerings to individual differences so that all learners can be supported appropriately.
pages.glossary.elements.sources: Bartel, Dörringer & Klopp, 2022a; Petko & Reusser, 2005, p. 188; Stangl, 2022, p. 1

pages.glossary.elements.definition: Adaptive content presentation refers to adapting the content or presentation of a page based on an individual learner’s characteristics. For example, learners with higher prior knowledge may receive more detailed information, while learners with lower prior knowledge receive additional explanations. Presentation can also be adapted to preferences such as favoring graphics over text.

Adaptive navigation support helps learners find their way through a system. It includes various adaptation techniques; in HASKI, this is implemented through adaptive link annotation, where the next recommended action is highlighted.

An adaptive learning system (also referred to as an Intelligent Tutoring System, Adaptive Educational System, or Personalized Learning Environment) aims to adapt to the needs and learning goals of individual learners. In HASKI, this is based on three models: the learner model, the tutorial model, and the domain model.
Animations present learning content in an animated multimedia format. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.
Real-life applications show how learned material can be applied in real-world situations. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.
Examples provide concrete illustrations of theoretical concepts. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.

An educational setting is any environment in which learning and educational activities take place. Learners may engage in lectures, discussions, group work, or independent study to acquire knowledge, skills, and competencies. Educational settings vary in size, structure, and focus depending on educational level, subject area, and target audience.

The domain model contains metadata for all topics, digital learning spaces, and learning elements within the learning environment, including the domain’s basic structure. It also captures concepts, content, learning objects (e.g., examples, graphics, or exercises), and their relationships or dependencies.
Element progress represents the history of visited learning elements and indicates which learning elements have already been visited.
Content objects present the core learning material of a course. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.

Forum activities enable learners to ask questions and discuss topics with peers and instructors. While a course often has one forum, it can include multiple forum activities that encourage participation. In HASKI, forum activities are classified as a type of learning element.

In an educational context, feedback is information provided to learners about their progress, performance, and achievements. It can take the form of verbal comments, written comments, grades, or scores. Effective feedback is timely, specific, and constructive, focusing on the task or behavior and offering clear suggestions for improvement. Feedback may come from teachers, peers, or self-assessment and supports monitoring progress, sustaining motivation, and developing competencies.

The FSLSM distinguishes eight learning styles across four dimensions: processing (active vs. reflective), perception (sensory vs. intuitive), input modality (visual vs. verbal), and understanding (sequential vs. global). If there is no noticeable preference on a dimension, it is described as balanced (BAL).

Externally controlled learning refers to learning processes guided by external influences. These may include other people (e.g., teacher instructions), instructional media (e.g., computer programs), or the design of the learning environment.

pages.glossary.elements.term: Basic structure (of the domain model or the learning world)
pages.glossary.elements.definition: The basic structure of the learning world comprises all relationships and dependencies among topics, digital learning spaces, and learning elements from the teacher’s perspective.

The ILS questionnaire is used to determine an individual’s learning style. In its original English version, it contains 44 dichotomous questions, with 11 questions per dimension. Preferences are expressed on a scale from +11 to −11 per dimension: selecting option (a) increases the score by +1, while selecting option (b) decreases it by −1.

Competence refers to the cognitive abilities and skills individuals possess or can acquire to solve specific problems, as well as the associated motivational, volitional, and social dispositions that enable responsible and effective problem-solving in varying situations.

A course is the highest hierarchical level in the domain model structure. A course can include one or more topics and sub-topics that may be logically connected through learning paths, and within which learning processes take place.
Commentaries provide learners with a brief overview of a sub-topic. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.

Learning analytics refers to measuring, collecting, analyzing, and reporting data about learners and their contexts to understand and optimize learning and learning environments. In HASKI, learning analytics includes element progress, learning progress, ratings, time spent (duration and timing), learning sequences and repetitions, performance in test elements, demographic data (e.g., age, gender, semester, program, work experience), and grades.

A learning management system (LMS) is software that supports the administration of learning and training activities. It can register users, track courses, record learner data, and provide reports. LMSs are widely used to create, manage, and deliver course material and can support instructional and pedagogical activities through features such as assessment, personalization, and resource management.
pages.glossary.elements.sources: Hall, 2001; Kattoua, Al-Lozi & Alrowwad, 2016; Sabharwal et al., 2018; Turnbull, Chugh & Luck, 2019; Turnbull, Chugh & Luck, 2021, p. 164

pages.glossary.elements.definition: In HASKI, learner characteristics comprise individual attributes that are relevant for adaptive learning path design and/or shown in student and teacher dashboards. These characteristics are stored in the learner model and may include learning style tendencies, learning strategies, knowledge level, and learning analytics.

Learning elements support learners’ competence development and are provided within learning spaces. They may appear as verbal elements (e.g., written text, hypertext, spoken language), visual elements (e.g., static or moving images), and/or interactive formats (e.g., simulations, games, 3D). In the domain model hierarchy, learning elements form the lowest level and can be differentiated by classification types.
pages.glossary.elements.sources: Arnold, 2011, p. 138; Bartel, Dörringer & Klopp, 2022, p. 1

pages.glossary.elements.definition: HASKI can provide learning recommendations based on individual learner data and the structure of the domain model, supporting decisions about what to do next. Recommendations are communicated by visually highlighting suggested learning elements. The tutorial model combines information from the learner model and the domain model to generate individualized learning recommendations.

A learning format refers to the structure or arrangement in which educational content is presented to learners. It includes how information is organized, delivered, and accessed to facilitate learning. Examples range from lectures and textbooks to online courses and interactive multimedia. The choice of format depends on factors such as learning goals, target audience, and available resources and technology.
Learning progress indicates which learning elements have been completed and how successful the learner was while working on them.

The learner model in HASKI consists of multiple components that interact and influence each other. It is assumed to be dynamic and can change over time through new experiences, interactions, and knowledge acquisition, adapting to current requirements.

Learner satisfaction is the degree of contentment or positive emotional response learners experience regarding their learning experiences. It reflects engagement and motivation and includes aspects such as enjoyment of learning activities, perceived achievement of learning goals, perceived relevance, and satisfaction with the learning environment and support.

In online learning, a learning object is a self-contained unit of digital educational content (e.g., text, images, video, interactive elements) designed to address specific learning objectives and to be reusable across contexts. In HASKI, the term "learning element" is used instead of "learning object" because "learning object" is used inconsistently in broader educational contexts.

A learning pathway is a didactically planned, sequential composition of topics, learning spaces, and/or learning elements. Pathways may be created by teachers or by HASKI; the teacher-created structure is treated as the default pathway. Learning pathways can be linear (same order for all learners) or adaptive (adjusted to individual learners). In HASKI, the tutorial model adapts pathways based on data from the learner model and the basic structure of the domain model.
pages.glossary.elements.sources: Bartel, Dörringer & Klopp, 2022, p. 1; Goertz, 2015; Hessisches Kultusministerium, 2016; Niegemann & Heidig, 2020, p. 362; Paramythis & Loidl-Reisinger, 2004; Pöhler, 2018; Roth, 2014

pages.glossary.elements.definition: Physical learning spaces are locations where teachers and learners meet and engage in learning activities; they can be understood as physical containers as well as perceptual, action, and social spaces. In HASKI, face-to-face sessions conducted in combination with the HASKI system (following a blended-learning approach) are referred to as physical learning spaces.

In HASKI, a learning sequence is a limited sequence of learning elements that a learner visits. Unlike a learning pathway, a learning sequence is not didactically planned. It is also distinct from a learning way, which represents the totality of a learner’s sequences over time.

The learning state is the individualized part of the learner model. It includes information such as element progress, learning style, learning strategies, knowledge level, and additional learning analytics. It is visible only to the learner, while teachers can access aggregated averages across learners.

Learning styles are relatively stable individual indicators reflecting preferences in processing, perceiving, organizing, and presenting information. They are considered situation- and task-independent and describe how learners interact with and respond to their learning environment.

In learning style recognition, "dynamic" refers to a system’s ability to adjust to changing learner needs and preferences over time. A dynamic approach continuously monitors and evaluates preferences and updates recommendations accordingly, rather than relying on a single, static assessment.

In learning style recognition, "static" refers to the assumption that a learner’s preferred learning style is fixed and does not change over time. This approach treats preferences as stable across contexts, in contrast to dynamic approaches that allow for change depending on time and situation.

Learning style recognition is the process of identifying an individual’s preferred way of learning by assessing tendencies related to approaching tasks, retaining information, and engaging with educational materials. The aim is to enable more personalized learning experiences and improve outcomes and motivation.

Learning style theories describe the idea that learners differ in how they prefer to process information and approach learning, and that instruction can be adapted accordingly. Various models classify learners based on dimensions such as sensory modalities, environmental influences, and emotional factors.

In HASKI, learning strategies are behaviors learners use deliberately to acquire knowledge. They support obtaining, processing, organizing, and storing information effectively. Learning strategies are an individual characteristic composed of multiple components with varying levels of expression; in HASKI, they are currently assessed using LIST-K.

A learning environment is the physical, social, and psychological context in which learning takes place. It includes conditions, resources, and interactions, such as classrooms or online platforms, relationships with teachers and peers, tools and technologies, and the cultural and emotional climate that shapes engagement and motivation.

Learner behaviour refers to observable actions, attitudes, and interactions during learning. It includes how learners engage with tasks and materials, participate in discussions, seek help, manage time, and regulate their learning. Understanding learner behaviour can inform instructional design and tailored support.

A learning way is the actual sequence of actions taken by an individual learner. It may differ from the planned learning pathway for a learning space. Observed learning ways can provide insights into learning behaviour, knowledge level, and preferences; differences between planned pathways and actual learning ways of high-performing learners may also indicate pathway quality and fit.
Assignments describe requirements learners must meet for course assessment. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.

The LIST-K questionnaire is a shortened version of the original "Learning Strategies in Studies" (LIST). It reduces the number of items to improve test economy while maintaining reliability. LIST-K distinguishes cognitive strategies, metacognitive strategies, management of internal resources, and management of external resources, each with multiple subscales.

Metadata describe topics, digital learning spaces, and learning elements in more detail. Categories include identifiers, authorship, dates, course assignment, target group, semester, short descriptions, difficulty level, learning analytics metrics, positioning in the learning world, and relations within the basic structure. For learning elements, additional fields include classification type, file type, supporting or hindering FSLSM dimensions, and influencing learning strategies.

Reflective quizzes include one or more open-ended questions about a section’s content. They encourage learners to reflect on what they have learned. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.

Self-assessment tests include multiple closed-ended questions about a section’s content. They allow learners to check their knowledge and receive immediate feedback on their answers. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.

Self-controlled learning describes a form of learning in which learners have substantial agency and decide which content, tools, and didactic approaches best meet their needs. Learners take self-regulating measures aligned with given and self-determined goals, depending on motivation and situational requirements, to monitor, regulate, and evaluate their learning process.

A sub-topic contains one or more learning elements that learners can visit and work on. Learning elements can be logically linked via learning pathways. In the domain model hierarchy, sub-topics are positioned one level above learning elements.

In HASKI, a topic is a logically connected area within a course that groups related sub-topics. In exceptional cases, a topic may contain only one sub-topic. In the hierarchy, the topic level sits between course and sub-topic.

The tutorial model in HASKI is responsible for generating individualized learning pathways and communicating them via learning recommendations. It uses data from the learner model and the basic structure of the domain model to determine what should be recommended to an individual learner. This decision-making may be based on AI models or rule-based methods and includes information about when specific learning content should be recommended.
Exercises give learners the opportunity to apply and practice what they have learned. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.

Knowledge level describes how familiar a learner is with central topics or concepts of a knowledge domain. In HASKI, it is part of the learner model and is initially elicited through a prior-knowledge test. It is updated over time as learners successfully complete learning elements, learning spaces, and topics; initially, HASKI models declarative knowledge as verbalizable factual knowledge.
pages.glossary.elements.sources: Brusilovsky & Millán, 2005; Cranach & Bangerter, 2000, pp. 235–236; Uhing, 2004, p. 102

pages.glossary.elements.definition: Conclusions summarize the learning content presented in the content object. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.

Additional reading materials provide learners with further sources related to a sub-topic, such as more detailed explanations or alternative perspectives. In HASKI, they are classified as a type of learning element.

pages.imprint.subtitle: HASKI Teaching/Learning Platform from the Software Development Lab at Kempten University
pages.login.redirect: You will be redirected after a few seconds
pages.privacypolicy.dataCollectionText: The data collection will be supervised by appropriately trained staff members of the HASKI project and conducted online using Moodle and the HASKI system. If you have any questions about the data collection process or need further information, please feel free to contact the designated persons listed below. The collected data will be processed confidentially.
pages.privacypolicy.dataProcessingText: After recording, the data will be analyzed by scientific staff members of the HASKI project. The scientific staff members responsible for data analysis have no conflicts of interest with the participating individuals (e.g., evaluation situations). As part of the analysis, transcripts and/or copies of the data may be created. These copies will be anonymized, meaning that all names and other information that could identify you as an individual will be removed.
pages.privacypolicy.informationStudyText: Within the HASKI project, the OTH Regensburg, HS Kempten, and TH Aschaffenburg are investigating how artificial intelligence can be used to support students in their learning. The goal of the project is to create an adaptive learning management system that provides learners with the best possible learning materials. The first version of this system, called HASKI Alpha, will now be tested regarding the impact of learning style-based learning paths on the motivation, interest, and knowledge of participating students. The focus is on the different algorithms underlying the learning paths. This approach is being used and tested for the first time in the study presented to you.
pages.privacypolicy.privacyNoticeHandlin: In the following, we will inform you about the privacy-compliant handling of your personal data. If you have any questions or difficulties understanding, please contact the study leader. We thank you for your participation and trust in our work! We comply with the provisions of the General Data Protection Regulation and all other data protection regulations. The following data will be collected as part of this study:
pages.privacypolicy.privacyNoticeIntenti: We intend to use this data as outlined below:
pages.privacypolicy.privacySupport: For inquiries regarding data protection issues, please contact the data protection officer. The data protection officer can be reached at the following contact details:
pages.privacypolicy.privacySupportName: Data Protection Officer of HS Kempten
pages.privacypolicy.publicationParagraph: Art. 7(3) GDPR - Right to withdraw consent: You have the right to withdraw your consent at any time with effect for the future.
Art. 15 GDPR - Right of access: You have the right to obtain information about the personal data we process about you.
Art. 16 GDPR - Right to rectification: If the data concerning you is incorrect or incomplete, you have the right to have it rectified or completed.
Art. 17 GDPR - Right to erasure: You can request the deletion of your data at any time.
Art. 18 GDPR - Right to restriction of processing: You can request the restriction of processing of your personal data.
Art. 21 GDPR - Right to object: You can object to the processing of your personal data at any time.

Art. 77 GDPR - Right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority: If you believe that we have not complied with data protection regulations in the processing of your data, you have the right to lodge a complaint with the relevant supervisory authority, which will review your complaint.
pages.privacypolicy.publicationText-1: Research findings will be published in publications or conferences solely in anonymized form, and at no point will it allow any identification of you as an individual. No personal data (such as name or contact information) will be published.
pages.privacypolicy.publicationText-2: You have the right to exercise the following rights at any time:
pages.privacypolicy.publicationText-3: In any case, your participation in the data collection is voluntary. You have the right to withdraw at any time. Refusal or withdrawal will not result in any disadvantages for you.
pages.privacypolicy.publicationText-4: For compliance with data protection regulations in the case of this study, HS Kempten is responsible.
pages.privacypolicy.storageAndAccessText: The data will be securely stored in digital form on the server of the HASKI project and will only be accessible to authorized staff members of the HASKI project. The data collected in this study will be kept in an anonymized form in a trusted archive for good scientific practice and will be used by other researchers. The anonymized data may also be used for educational purposes under controlled conditions. Your data will be retained by the HASKI project for a maximum of 10 years and will be irreversibly deleted after this period.
pages.privacypolicy.support: If you have any questions about the study, please contact the principal investigator. In the case of this study, the contact person is:
pages.projectdescription.advantagesLearn: The support is enabled by the HASKI system reading your data from Moodle and using an AI algorithm based on this data to suggest a personalized learning path through the learning materials. Of course, the decision about which material you want to work on next remains with you. HASKI also remembers these preferences and adjusts future suggestions to new circumstances.

The data basis consists of questionnaires, individual knowledge levels, evaluated tasks, and behavioral data from Moodle. Through anonymization of data, a conclusion about you by instructors is prevented.
Benefits for you in your studies
What data does HASKI work with?
pages.projectdescription.advantagesTeach: The HASKI system aims to make a significant contribution to establishing interactive, personalized, and self-directed learning in higher education. Digital media and platforms can provide much more than the current practice of higher education, which is dominated by traditional classroom teaching, even in the context of the pandemic.

The idea behind HASKI is to harness the potential of AI in the courses offered at University of Applied Sciences Kempten. This is achieved by combining in-person teaching, the learning management system (e.g. Moodle), and the HASKI system. With this we provide a software component that utilizes AI algorithms to assist you in achieving your learning goals.
pages.projectdescription.approachesBody: National exchange. Publication of scientific contributions. Presentations at german conferences.
Application of state-of-the-art technology. Combination of learning analytics and artificial intelligence.
Empirical investigations. Online surveys, evaluation studies, data analysis.
pages.projectdescription.goalsBody: Improvement and expansion of existing courses in the field of software engineering through the production of high-quality, pedagogically meaningful, and varied learning content
Comprehensive digital representation of individual students and their characteristics
Development of an adaptive and AI-based learning system for generating personalized learning path recommendations
AI-based evaluation of exercises and helpful feedback
Visualization and preparation of learning analytics to reflect on learning behavior
Didactically relevant reports for lecturers to improve courses
pages.projectdescription.introductionBod: HASKI stands for "Hochschullehre: Adaptiv, selbstgesteuert, KI-gestützt" ("Higher education teaching: Adaptive, self-directed, AI-assisted") and is funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research with a project duration until December 2025. HASKI is a collaborative project of three Bavarian universities: OTH Regensburg, Aschaffenburg UAS & Kempten UAS.
